message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. HAART (highly active antiretroviral therapy) is the appropriate management for a pregnant woman with HIV infection, as it can decrease the risk of transmission to the fetus. Antibiotic prophylaxis is not relevant to HIV infection, and breastfeeding can transmit the virus to the infant. Mode of delivery (vaginal or cesarean) will depend on individual factors such as viral load and obstetric indications.

We refer to CDC guidelines for help. The patient’s CD4 count indicates immunosuppression, and therefore antiretroviral therapy (HAART) is recommended during pregnancy to reduce the risk of vertical transmission of HIV to the fetus. Antibiotic prophylaxis may also be recommended for certain infections, but it is not mentioned in the question stem. Breastfeeding is contraindicated in HIV-infected mothers due to the risk of vertical transmission. The mode of delivery (vaginal or cesarean) will depend on the patient’s viral load closer to delivery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. This patient has a low CD4 count and a high viral load, indicating a more advanced stage of HIV infection. The appropriate management would be to start highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) to reduce transmission to the fetus and lower the risk of progression of the disease. Antibiotic prophylaxis may be necessary, and breastfeeding should be avoided due to the risk of transmission. The mode of delivery should be determined based on other factors such as obstetric indications and maternal viral load.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a low CD4 count and high viral load, indicating that she should be treated with highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) to reduce transmission of the virus to the fetus. Antibiotic prophylaxis may be indicated to prevent opportunistic infections, and vaginal delivery is possible if the maternal viral load is well-controlled. Breastfeeding should be avoided due to the risk of transmission of the virus to the infant.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. In cases of HIV-infected pregnant women, HAART is recommended to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission. Antibiotic prophylaxis may be necessary to prevent certain opportunistic infections. Breastfeeding is contraindicated in HIV-infected women because it can transmit the virus to the infant. Vaginal delivery can also increase the risk of transmission, so a scheduled C-section may be recommended. However, the question only asks for appropriate management of the pregnancy, and HAART is the most appropriate management in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's CD4 count suggests that her immune system is already compromised, and her viral load indicates a high level of HIV in her body. HAART (Highly Active Antiretroviral Therapy) is the appropriate management for her pregnancy to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission of HIV. Antibiotic prophylaxis may be needed to prevent opportunistic infections. Breastfeeding should be avoided because HIV can be transmitted through breast milk. Vaginal delivery can also increase the risk of transmission of HIV to the newborn, and may need to be avoided depending on the patient's viral load and other factors. Cesarean delivery may be recommended in some cases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. In a pregnant woman with HIV, highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) is the appropriate management to reduce the risk of HIV transmission to the neonate. Antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended to help prevent opportunistic infections in HIV-infected individuals but is not specific to pregnancy. Breastfeeding is contraindicated due to the risk of mother-to-child transmission. Vaginal delivery may be an option depending on the patient’s viral load, but HAART is still recommended regardless of the mode of delivery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. HIV-positive pregnant women should be started on highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) as soon as possible to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission. Antibiotic prophylaxis is not appropriate management for HIV infection during pregnancy. Breastfeeding is contraindicated for HIV-positive mothers due to the risk of transmission. Vaginal delivery may be the preferred mode of delivery if the woman's viral load is low, but in this case, her high viral load requires careful consideration and discussion with an HIV specialist.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. HIV infection during pregnancy carries risks to both the mother and the fetus. In this case, the patient’s low CD4 count and high viral load require management with Highly Active Antiretroviral Therapy (HAART) to suppress viral replication and reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission. Antibiotic prophylaxis and vaginal delivery may also be indicated, but this depends on other factors such as the patient’s overall health and obstetric history. Breastfeeding is contraindicated due to the risk of transmission of the virus through breast milk.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a low CD4 count and high viral load, which indicate the need for Highly Active Antiretroviral Therapy (HAART) to prevent vertical transmission of HIV to the infant. Avoidance of antibiotic prophylaxis is not recommended, and breastfeeding is contraindicated in HIV-positive mothers. Vaginal delivery may be possible, but it should be discussed with the patient's healthcare provider and may depend on the patient's clinical status near the time of delivery.
